channel.title: The Developers' Bakery
channel.description: A developer podcast about tools, libraries, and productivity. The Developers' Bakery is a place for open-source developers and maintainers to share their experience and projects. A journey through the tools and libraries that help developers worldwide baking great software daily. Join Nicola Corti through this journey among open source and beyond.
channel.itunes:summary: A developer podcast about tools, libraries, and productivity. The Developers' Bakery is a place for open-source developers and maintainers to share their experience and projects. A journey through the tools and libraries that help developers worldwide baking great software daily. Join Nicola Corti through this journey among open source and beyond.
channel.itunes:author: Nicola Corti
channel.itunes:subtitle: A developer podcast about tools, libraries, and productivity. Featuring open-source developers and maintainers sharing their own experiences.

item.title: VelocityX and Flutter with Pawan Kumar
item.itunes:title: VelocityX and Flutter with Pawan Kumar
item.dc:creator: Nicola Corti
item.itunes:subtitle: It's time to talk about Flutter and Cross-platform development with Pawan Kumar and his framework VelocityX.
item.itunes:summary: It's time to talk about Flutter and Cross-platform development with Pawan Kumar and his framework VelocityX.
item.description: Do you know Flutter üíô ? I bet you do, if you‚Äôre into mobile development. Today, we have Pawan Kumar on stage, he‚Äôs a Flutter & Dart GDE and he is on stage to advocate for cross-platform development. Pawan is the author of VelocityX, a framework that will make your...
item.content:encoded:
Do you know Flutter üíô ? I bet you do, if you‚Äôre into mobile development. Today, we have Pawan Kumar on stage, he‚Äôs a Flutter & Dart GDE and he is on stage to advocate for cross-platform development.

Pawan is the author of VelocityX, a framework that will make your UI development experience even faster. He will tell us more about this framework, how it started and what the inspiration came from.

Also, make sure to don‚Äôt miss the bonus question Kotlin vs Dart (39:50) ‚ÅâÔ∏è

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

  • 00:37 Intro
  • 01:12 Episode Start
  • 02:02 Pawan‚Äôs Introduction
  • 03:00 What is Flutter?
  • 05:11 Android Native vs Flutter?
  • 08:12 Kotlin Multiplatform vs Flutter?
  • 10:43 What is VelocityX?
  • 15:51 VelocityX Key Features
  • 18:12 State Management & VelocityX
  • 20:41 Who is using VelocityX?
  • 22:58 Open-source examples?
  • 24:50 What inspired VelocityX?
  • 28:30 Is VelocityX production ready?
  • 30:02 What‚Äôs missing in VelocityX?
  • 32:35 Contributing to VelocityX
  • 34:50 VelocityX‚Äôs future
  • 37:36 Learning Material
  • 38:50 Where to find Pawan online?
  • 39:50 Bonus question: Kotlin vs Dart?

Resources

  • VelocityX on Github
  • VelocityX Official Documentation
  • VxToast #1 - Flutter Meets VelocityX

  • PortfolioX Sample App

  • Other mentioned frameworks and packages:
    • provider package for Flutter
    • Tailwind CSS
    • Swift UI

item.title: Koin with Arnaud Giuliani
item.itunes:title: Koin with Arnaud Giuliani
item.dc:creator: Nicola Corti
item.itunes:subtitle: Are you up for some Dependency Injection? Because today we have Arnaud Giuliani on stage, to talk about Koin, a DI framework for Kotlin, Android and more!
item.itunes:summary: Are you up for some Dependency Injection? Because today we have Arnaud Giuliani on stage, to talk about Koin, a DI framework for Kotlin, Android and more!
item.description: In this episode, we talk about Dependency Injection üó°. We have Arnaud Giuliani on stage, Kotlin GDE and author of Koin, a popular dependency injection framework for Kotlin. Koin works well for Android projects, but it can be used also in backend projects and the Multiplatform support is just behind...
item.content:encoded:
In this episode, we talk about Dependency Injection üó°. We have Arnaud Giuliani on stage, Kotlin GDE and author of Koin, a popular dependency injection framework for Kotlin.

Koin works well for Android projects, but it can be used also in backend projects and the Multiplatform support is just behind the corner.

Arnaud will tell us the story of this framework: how it started, how it grew and how its feature will look like.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

  • 00:36 Intro
  • 01:11 Episode Start
  • 01:46 Arnaud‚Äôs Introduction
  • 03:20 What is Koin?
  • 04:47 Reified Types & Annotations
  • 08:48 The path to success
  • 11:42 Koin‚Äôs killer feature
  • 13:47 What is missing in Koin?
  • 15:21 Compile time verification
  • 18:35 The DI ecosystem
  • 20:56 Koin in the Android world
  • 23:56 Koin in the Multiplatform world
  • 28:10 Koin internals
  • 31:00 Kotlin‚Äôs feature used by Koin
  • 32:08 What‚Äôs new in Koin 3.x
  • 35:16 Breaking API Changes
  • 39:24 Koin 4.x?
  • 42:35 How to contribute to Koin?
  • 46:46 Learning Material
  • 49:41 Where to find Arnaud online?

item.title: Starship with Matan Kushner
item.itunes:title: Starship with Matan Kushner
item.dc:creator: Nicola Corti
item.itunes:subtitle: Today we talk about Starship, the minimal, blazing-fast and infinitely customizable prompt shell with its author Matan Kushner
item.itunes:summary: Today we talk about Starship, the minimal, blazing-fast and infinitely customizable prompt shell with its author Matan Kushner
item.description: In this episode, we shift a bit from Mobile & Kotlin to talk about shells, prompts and Rust! ü¶Ä Today we have Matan Kushner with us on stage to talk about Starship üöÄ. From their website: The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell! Still confused? A picture...
item.content:encoded:
In this episode, we shift a bit from Mobile & Kotlin to talk about shells, prompts and Rust! ü¶Ä

Today we have Matan Kushner with us on stage to talk about Starship üöÄ. From their website: The minimal, blazing-fast, and infinitely customizable prompt for any shell!

Still confused? A picture is worth a thousand words:

Starship in action, from starship.rs

If you‚Äôre curious to know more about shells, prompts, customizations and what are the challenges behind Starship, make sure you don‚Äôt this episode.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

  • 00:27 Intro
  • 01:13 Episode Start
  • 01:53 Matan‚Äôs Introduction

  • 13:36 Is there a ‚Äúprompt market‚Äù?

  • 19:40 Where is Starship collecting information?

  • 22:37 Which shell is the hardest to work with

item.title: Jetpack Compose Desktop with Sebastian Aigner
item.itunes:title: Jetpack Compose Desktop with Sebastian Aigner
item.dc:creator: Nicola Corti
item.itunes:subtitle: Directly from JetBrains, we have Sebastian Aigner on stage to talk about Jetpack Compose Desktop, the new desktop UI declarative framework from JB.
item.itunes:summary: Directly from JetBrains, we have Sebastian Aigner on stage to talk about Jetpack Compose Desktop, the new desktop UI declarative framework from JB.
item.description: Today, I‚Äôm more than excited to welcome on stage Sebastian Aigner, Developer Advocate at JetBrains. Sebastian is with us to talk about Jetpack Compose Desktop, a new declarative UI framework for Desktop applications written in Kotlin. Jetpack Compose Desktop is the porting of Jetpack Compose, the declarative UI framework for...
item.content:encoded:
Today, I‚Äôm more than excited to welcome on stage Sebastian Aigner, Developer Advocate at JetBrains.

Sebastian is with us to talk about Jetpack Compose Desktop, a new declarative UI framework for Desktop applications written in Kotlin.

Jetpack Compose Desktop is the porting of Jetpack Compose, the declarative UI framework for Android. JetBrains took the Compose to the next level offering a lot of new APIs and tools to make Desktop UI development a pleasure again. The project gained a lot of popularity recently on Github.

Sebastian is here to talk about his experience with the tool, how to write your first Compose Desktop application and how to contribute to the framework.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

  • 00:27 Intro
  • 01:13 Episode Start
  • 01:44 Sebastian‚Äôs Introduction
  • 03:14 What is Jetpack Compose Desktop?
  • 04:37 Jetpack Compose for Android
  • 05:35 Desktop and UIs
  • 07:30 Why not Jetbrains UI?
  • 09:12 It just works TM
  • 09:42 Package naming
  • 10:21 Supported platforms
  • 11:43 Migrating existing applications
  • 13:42 The next Compose Desktop app from JB?
  • 14:39 How to contribute to Ccompose Desktop?

  • 18:35 Where to provide feedback?
  • 19:49 Where to find support?
  • 20:55 Official Compose Desktop Examples
  • 23:17 Seb‚Äôs experience with Compose Desktop
  • 28:49 What is still missing in Compose Desktop?
  • 30:07 Push notifications on Desktop
  • 31:44 What‚Äôs the future for Compose Desktop?
  • 33:01 Compose for Web!?
  • 34:41 Learning material
  • 36:30 Where to find Seb online?

item.title: Danger with Franco Meloni

item.dc:creator: Nicola Corti
item.itunes:subtitle: Time to kick-off 2021 with an amazing tool to automatize your pull-requests: Danger, and Franco Meloni is on stage to present it!
item.itunes:summary: Time to kick-off 2021 with an amazing tool to automatize your pull-requests: Danger, and Franco Meloni is on stage to present it!
item.description: Let‚Äôs kickoff 2021 with a great open-source tool: danger ‚ö†Ô∏è! Danger‚Äôs motto is Stop saying ‚ÄúYou forgot to‚Ä¶‚Äù in code review and it definitely delivers greatly on promises. With Danger, you can automatize recurrent and tedious tasks that affect your pull-requests. Today, we have Franco Meloni on stage, one of...
item.content:encoded:
Let‚Äôs kickoff 2021 with a great open-source tool: danger ‚ö†Ô∏è! Danger‚Äôs motto is Stop saying ‚ÄúYou forgot to‚Ä¶‚Äù in code review and it definitely delivers greatly on promises. With Danger, you can automatize recurrent and tedious tasks that affect your pull-requests.

Today, we have Franco Meloni on stage, one of the maintainer of danger/swift & danger/kotlin that will tell us the recipe for a friction-less pull code-review process.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

item.title: Coil with Colin White
item.itunes:title: Coil with Colin White
item.dc:creator: Nicola Corti
item.itunes:subtitle: Colin is here to introduce Coil, Coroutine Image Loader. A library to reshape image loading on Android
item.itunes:summary: Colin is here to introduce Coil, Coroutine Image Loader. A library to reshape image loading on Android
item.description: In this episode, we welcome on stage Colin White to introduce us Coil, COroutines Image Loader. Coil is an Android image loading library that recently hit the 1.0 milestone, completely written in Kotlin and with first class support for Kotlin Coroutines. In this episode, Colin tells us challenges, fun facts...
item.content:encoded:
In this episode, we welcome on stage Colin White to introduce us Coil, COroutines Image Loader. Coil is an Android image loading library that recently hit the 1.0 milestone, completely written in Kotlin and with first class support for Kotlin Coroutines. In this episode, Colin tells us challenges, fun facts and future projects for this library.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

  • 00:20 Intro
  • 01:06 Episode Start
  • 02:00 Colin‚Äôs Introduction

  • 25:32 Prefetching and Animating
  • 28:58 Challenges in the Open Source ecosystems
  • 30:42 How to contribute?
  • 32:24 The future of Coil
  • 34:09 Learning Coil
  • 35:17 Where to find Colin online?

item.title: Gradle Doctor with Nelson Osacky
item.itunes:title: Gradle Doctor with Nelson Osacky
item.dc:creator: Nicola Corti
item.itunes:subtitle: Nelson presents gradle-doctor, a tool to get prescriptions for your inefficient Gradle build
item.itunes:summary: Nelson presents gradle-doctor, a tool to get prescriptions for your inefficient Gradle build
item.description: In this episode, we talk about Gradle Doctor with its author Nelson Osacky. Gradle doctor helps you fix performance problems and errors in your Gradle build. The tool works as a Gradle plugin - emitting prescriptions for all the problems found. Nelson tells us how he came up with the...
item.content:encoded:
In this episode, we talk about Gradle Doctor with its author Nelson Osacky. Gradle doctor helps you fix performance problems and errors in your Gradle build. The tool works as a Gradle plugin - emitting prescriptions for all the problems found. Nelson tells us how he came up with the idea behind this tool, and what the future is for Gradle Doctor.

Enjoy the show üë®‚Äçüç≥

Show Notes

  • 0:20 Intro
  • 1:06 Episode Start
  • 1:49 Nelson‚Äôs Introduction
  • 04:22 What is Gradle Doctor?
  • 08:44 Remote build cache
  • 16:19 JAVA_HOME madness
  • 21:36 The most common mistake in your build.gradle
  • 24:34 Gradle Doctor and performance
  • 31:17 Extensibility
  • 33:12 The future of Gradle Doctor
  • 39:56 Where to find Nelson online?

Resources

  • runningcode/gradle-doctor on Github
  • Gradle Doctor Documentation
  • How fast does my internet need to be to use the Gradle Remote Build Cache? - Part 1 and Part 2

item.title: Show Trailer

item.dc:creator: Nicola Corti
item.itunes:subtitle: Welcome to The Developers's Bakery
item.itunes:summary: Hi everyone and welcome to the Developers' Bakery. A podcast about open-source projects, tools and libraries for software developers.
item.description: Show Notes Hi everyone and welcome to the Developers Bakery üëã A podcast about open-source projects, tools and libraries for software developers. If you ever developed any kind of software, you probably know that a significant amount of code is not the one you wrote but the one others wrote....
item.content:encoded:
Show Notes

Hi everyone and welcome to the Developers Bakery üëã

A podcast about open-source projects, tools and libraries for software developers.

If you ever developed any kind of software, you probably know that a significant amount of code is not the one you wrote but the one others wrote. Frameworks, Libraries and SDKs are the building blocks to write great software for our end users. It‚Äôs just unthinkable to reinvent the wheel every time, right?

In this show we will meet authors and maintainers of libraries that are used worldwide to bake great software every day. We will hear stories from the open source community and learn what is happening behind the scenes of famous tools and projects.

My name is Nicola Corti and I‚Äôll be your host for this show.

Make sure you subscribe to the podcast on either Spotify, Apple Podcasts, Google Podcasts or directly from the website thebakery.dev. To be notified of the latest episodes, you can follow the show as @thebakerydev on twitter.

And if you have a tool or a library to share, feel free to drop me a message on the contact form on the website.

That being said, enjoy the show! üéô

Resources

  • Podcast Website
  • The Developers Bakery on Spotify
  • The Developers Bakery on Apple Podcasts
  • The Developers Bakery on Google Podcasts
  • @thebakerydev on Twitter
  • @cortinico on Twitter
item.itunes:author: Nicola Corti
